Despite the tedious combat, this is a really good RPG game. It's somewhat short and quite linear, but there's enough interesting content in it to keep you busy for at least 20 hours. While a lot of the features are a tad superfluous. there is a good story, plenty of quests and a lot of interesting places to visit. The moral choices you have to make really add to the game. The only downside of the game is that the (melee) combat is just a lot of clicking. The training about blocking that you receive early in the game is rendered completely useless because you're (almost) always attacked by more than one enemy. Still it only lengthens the battles and doesn't really make them harder.  Recommended for 10$ and a no-brainer for anybody who likes RPGs when it's on sale.

Fable: The Lost Chapters Fable is one of the first M games I had ever been allowed to play when I was younger, and I believe that even now, it has aged gracefully. In Fable, it is simply astounding to the amount of interactions you can have with people. Sneer at them, scare the crap out of them, and children will run in terror at your approach. Or, become the saint that all love and respect, and give everyone a gift or two. Or, give 'em the middle finger and tell 'em to ♥♥♥♥ off. Then say sorry. Then ask a gay man to marry you. Reputation is everything in this game, be you good or evil, a good reputation for being good or evil is still a necessity. Or, live between the lines, but there are times that playing around with your alignment is not the way to go, and only one choice can be made. That choice, however, is entirely up to you. While the game does not entirely match up to some of the graphics of today, this game looks very beautyful and full of life, or death, especialy for it's time. The gameplay is very simple as well, and combat against multiple enemies can be fun, easy, very action packed once you get used to it. The replay value is actualy suprisingly high for the kind of game it is, and I'll tell you, I played this game on the XBOX dozens of times, each time telling myself I would become a different person, and each time, I found out something new about the game. I will say that if there is anyone out there who wishes to test their fantasy of a Hero or Villian, come along and experience the game that changed the way games were made.   9.5/10

I always had heard the general misconception that Fable games are bad, or rather disappointing. I delved into this world looking for high fantasy with no questions asked, and it seemed like the right game for me. I kept seeing people saying 2 and 3 were bad, and that Fable the Lost Chapters was the best in the series, but I was still a bit, if not a lot, hesitant. I doubted and doubted, but I made up my mind and decided to purchase it and play it blind without knowing what is going on. As you may see I yet have to finish the game, but I cannot resist the need to just yell out how great, how excellent this game is. It strives for realism and achieves it in a 'videogamey' way. It is action packed and the decisions to be good or evil are very fun. The world does change around you. People hail you if you're good and loathe you if you're evil, even running away from you. You can marry shallow but good-looking characters, and the game even makes fun of itself in this aspect on a book in which it incites you to murder your beloved just because you're bored of him or her. It is great, simply and absurdly great, and it was a real surprise for me to see this game be so good. 9/10 would give a wedding ring to the Guildmaster again.  By the way, do not bother with anniversary, play this one, the real one, and see why it doesn't even deserve a remake.

This version is superior to the original release. The game is not particularly demanding, so even older computers should be able to run the game without experiencing issues. If you like action RPGs it's worth trying out. Your choices have a far greater impact on your character's growth and appearance than newer games that boast a similar morality system. You're free to build your character as you see fit, instead of being limited by equipment and skill restrictions placed on typical RPG character classes. Not all combinations may be effective, but that's up to you to discover. It's a fun game that doesn't have a difficult learning curve, with added replayability that comes from the morality system.

I played Fable on the Original Xbox almost a decade ago and back then I stated that Fable was 'the best game I had ever played'- of course, better games have come along since then and have swept that title away from Fable's grasp, but that doesn't demote the fact that this game is an absolute masterpiece not only for its time, but by todays standards too.  I'm sort of nervous writing this 'review'- not because I fear the criticism I may get in return for creating it because I doubt they'll be any, but more for the fact that I want this game to get the good review it deserves as I absolutely adore this game, nonetheless, let me get into why.   Unlike most RPG's that force you to go down one linear path, Fable grants you the freedom to set which moral allignment you want to persue which will determine how you look visually and how people will treat you. If you chose to be evil, you will grow horns, flies will start to fly around you and villagers will boo and scream when they see you however if you chose to be good, you will grow a halo, butterflies will start to fly around you and villagers will cheer and compliment you when they see you- it's the tiny details that come together to make this game great. One thing I must critisize is the lack of sublety when making a moral decision, sometimes it can be so obvious that it's just 'press the LMB to be good and the RMB to be evil', which although it's still nice to be given the option, could of be relayed in a better way to the player.   The quests are actually interesting and never feel like a grind, gracefully not following the usual way of modern RPGs in the sense that all the work goes into the main questline and the side quests are just 'kill, fetch and return'. The characters are memorable and will stick with you throughout the game. The storyline, although starting to get slightly confusing halfway through, is still gripping.   If you've watched any videos about Peter Molyneux preaching Fable by lying and building it up to be better than what it is, then I'd understand why you'd be disappointed playing the game, however if you haven't and have just stumbled upon this review either by accident or by sheer curiousity, I'm almost certain that if you're an avid fan of RPG's that this will become one of your favourites for life.

I loved this game when I had it on Xbox. I have heard and seen it as being one of the most disapointing games of it's time, but I loved it. I went into the game blind, and loved it. I think it was because it was expected to be much more, but I was very happy where it was. It had plenty of action, a good story, great characters, and a lot of humor. It had a quite ElderScrolls feel to the leveling up. Instead of like most RPGs, where you get EXP from killing enemies and used that to level up, Fable is a bit different. You do get EXP from killing, but you also get it from doing the killing. You shoot something with an arrow, you get skill EXP. Blast them with lightning, you get will EXP. Bash them with a hammer, you get strength EXP. They do not mix together, so you can't play as pure mage and have a high health. Not from Will EXP, at least. This is where the General EXP come in, the stuff you get from killing and quests. That can be put towards anything.   Also, what you do in the game effects your appearence. Like to crunch on little newborn chickens (yes, you can do that) and kill people? A red mist will rise from your feet and eyes, you will become pale, flies will be drawn to you like the corpses you leave behind, and you grow horns (also destroying the majority of your hairstyle). People will run in terror from you, and hate you though your power will keep them from doing anything. But if you play as good, people will flock to, you will get a halo and a beam of light when you stand still. I think your eyes change color, though it has been a long time. Max out strength and you will look like a bodybuilder. Will will make you glow. I can't remember what Skill does. Fighting badly leaves you with scars.  I could keep going on, but you should play it yourself. My only complaints are that the GuildMaster gets annoying 'Your health is low. Have you any potions, or food', and I am having trouble getting the game to run on my computer even though it should be able to run it no problem. But once I get it up and running I won't be doing much else.

Go play something else if you want gameplay, and avoid this one if you want a good story.

The game was one of my faves when it was released. Unlike most RPGs, there were immense amounts of choices on how to build, and essentially, how to play as well. There is a main storyline, of course, and a presecribed path to take, but the game does sell on its promised choose your destiny format.  That said, gameplay is quite broken in general, and takes adjustment if you wish to scrape by without the broken aspects. For instance, you can make money simply buy buying and selling stuff to the same shopowner, as his stocks of items fluctuate the cost. Additionally, the most broken skill in the game is Physical Shield, as it not only keeps you from taking any damage at all, but you don't get thrown around, and you never lose your precious combat multiplier, so long as you chug mana potions, and that helps break the game wide open for you. But, in general, any character can grind to the point of being all-powerful, with some time invested, of course, as any build path is open for any character, as even though 'Being good' or 'Being bad' does influence your skill pool minimally, it's even more minute because fluctuating between good and bad is not difficult (especially for being bad...).   All that aside, the game was pretty much the first game to give a hero any type of plotline choices that I saw, and I must commend them for that. However, the game has a poor look for being released on Steam nowadays, and only diehard plot enthusiasts or general gamers who want to experience it all will enjoy this. I had to buy it for old time's sake, and while it has managed to accrue a bit of playtime, I don't see many out there enjoying this for what it's worth in this age of gaming. I really don't know of anything like Fable still, and I enjoyed it more than Fable III (haven't played the others...), but getting through the early game will be hard to weather through to get to the better parts of the plotline and become strong enough to feel less than some shrimpy character at times. In my opinion, casters are very underpowered, partly because Physical Shield is so overpowered, and will sap your mana if you don't kill things fast enough as a caster. The other paths get so much more powerful, and I don't see why you'd even bother. Still a huge step in the right direction for a choose-your-own-path type adventure, but there is still a clearly prescribed path, like any adventure with an adversary. It just has good areas you can stray from the path a bit, and they will effect your destiny in various ways.  I checked... I played it on Steam for 2nd most hours compared to any reviewer, and that's not all that much... I don't know what that could mean for certain, but I'd guess that the majority of reviewers who upvoted it are in it for the nostalgia. It was a good game in its heyday, but I believe that the strengths of this game would be overshadowed too much by its weaknesses in today's gaming environment, even at its lower price. There are a number of games that deserve being carried over into today, but while this one is on the fence for me, I'm leaving my opinion where it was; This game doesn't hold enough appeal to stand out amongst today's games.

This game shows it's age. Not just in graphics, but in plotline. Maybe the voice acting and side quest mechanics were interesting at the time, but now? Meh. Specific points:  Marketed as a game where you could have influence in the world, but.... -You can be mayor. What does it mean to be mayor? Nothing. You don't do anything, noone reacts. -You can own property. What does it mean to own property? Not much. You can upgrade the furnishings, hang trophies on the wall, and collect rent. And then never go back, because why would you? -You can get married. Find one of the many nameless NPCs and stand in front of them to show off your manly pectorals. Then throw a ring at them. You now have access to the sex scene, which is a fade to black with suggestive voice acting. Never interact with your wife again. -You can be good or evil. What's the difference? Halos or demon horns. You could slaughter the innocent one day, vanquish the wicked the next, and that's totally fine.  The running theme is that none of these decisions impact the story greatly. You can occasionally choose: 'kill this dude' or 'don't kill this dude.' That'll affect 2 or 3 scenes. Basically doesn't matter.  Not sure what to say about the core gameplay. I found it very easy, but YMMV.  ====================================================== Response to first comment:  I am skeptical of your rebuttal, and examined faqs and forum posts to investigate.  Are you sure about that mayor thing? Everything indicates that it does nothing. I did learn that I COULD purchase and rent out buildings and businesses other than the marital homes in each town, but you have to kill the tenant to do so. Which...geez. Talk about a hostile takeover. *rimshot*   Anyway, nobody reacted to me as mayor. And no new properties became available for rent. All signs point to violent death being the only way other property becomes available.  Still not sure what the point of renting things out is. It'd take an awful lot of time just making the rounds accumulating rent to earn the money back, and what is there to spend the money on? There's some legendary sword you can buy with it I guess, but there's dozens of legendary weapons sitting around everywhere anyways. You can pour it into the temple of Avo to shift alignment over to good. That's something I guess, but getting good alignment just happened as a natural result of going through the main quest, since every monster or bandit killed gave some good alignment points.  Didn't realize the spouse would give gifts. So that's something.  All indications also point to never having a child of one's own, that was added in Fable 2. If you marry the right person in Bowerstone, and they happen to be a single parent of one of the children in the school, then the child may be brought along. No sign that the child would eventually act like you. The aging mechanic gets weird here too, since you might get married at age 30, get married, meet your stepchild, then advance levels to age 65 and the stepchild is still the same age.   Good and evil have more result than most of these other effects, but...eh. Complaining that I'm not locked in? Hm. Perhaps I would like to be locked in a little bit. Redemption and corruption stories are interesting, and I don't want to always have to be the stupendously good-aligned butterfly-attracting goodly hero of goodness just because I ate some Tofu one time, but yeah. When I decided to try the other alignment, it was unsatisfying. Swapping the extremes is just too easy, and too without consequence. It doesn't seem the game particularly cares. Townsfolk alternately run away from me or come around to applaud me, and both are kind of annoying. Big clusters of sound files all being played at once either way.  I don't know what your last comment is supposed to imply. Do you mean I shouldn't have needed to spend that much time to complete the main storyline? I could have dropped the sidequests and paid even less attention to the economy, I guess. Do you mean I should have realized that I could kill townspeople and buy their houses? I was definitely surprised to learn that, but I don't see why I would.

equal parts ambition met with cordial shallowness, fable is a flat oddity. mind you, its not a generic game, nor is it missing anything crucial on a macro scale. fable's problem is that it's severely undercooked. yet simplicity itself can be a virtue within a sphere of confidence. sometimes a basic expression is all that's required to get a point across. it is fable's hinted aspirations among its genre identity that breeds contempt, yet it is no issue with the game itself. from the very start, fable makes apparent that the experience is going to be humble and straightforward. although it works on realization, it's too hard to deny a contradiction of the premise as expected when compared to the actual function. a broad comparison that falls apart as easily as its made would be likening fable as a western legend of zelda. both games are humble and straightforward action hybrids with identical targeting systems, but one game is serious, and one game is not.  in fable and in ocarina of time, the protagonist is a hero of a long bloodline, whose struggle is an inevitable result of that bloodline. in zelda, this is serious business, but in fable, it is not. though it took a total reevaluation of every event in the game to get to this conclusion, truthfully it is evident from the beginning of the game. the expression system of this game, likely developed to allow interaction than anything I’m saying, can only function in an atmosphere of normalcy, unseriousness, and even ridiculousness. yet, though I say heroics in fable are par the course, every person in the world takes it in with awe and reverence anyway. it’s an utter contrast, how unserious and whimsical the things you do are, and how great and magnificent they’re transposed on the world scale. eventually, the two ends meet, and the hero does things worth praising, and it further drives this rift. I think a work should properly separate what is serious and what is not and fable struggles mightily in that regard.  being good or evil is still treated with incredible importance. there are, of course, mundane acts that boost your karma either way. killing townsfolk makes you evil, while killing bandits and some monsters makes you good, among various other things, but consistency is not what I refer to. fable’s plot ramps up into clearly selfish and unselfish choices coinciding the the plot. though your choices have little mention, it is true that you’re allowed to do great good or great evil, and it shapes the tone of the story even if the choices aren’t totally integrated into the plot development. the great contrast of the choices makes them significantly less effective if the player harbors little malice; to me there was a single choice and its foil, never amounting to much weight. those who enjoy acting out villainy will find fable more accommodating, I believe, because the sharp contrast will create more viable choices. to be mentioned, no other pretense is at stake. fable wouldn’t work with morally gray choices, its charm is its exaggeration. if anything at all is successful in fable’s narrative, it would be the grand moral choices.  now, to put it bluntly, the gameplay sucks. fable borrows from the beat ‘em up genre ignorantly. its combat can be likened to prince of persia, which is the worst model on the planet for combat. block stops every attack with no repercussions for blocking, so if required, you can be invincible at any time. enemies annoyingly have the incredible block too, with no wind up or downtime on any of their attacks, making all fodder near identical. which is to say, unsatisfying and irritating. animations are awkward and contact comes with no good feeling or fanfare. a few lame hits in, the enemy will block. when you’re blocked, or you successfully block, the hero’s weapon will glow purple. the other attack button will let the hero do a slightly more damaging guard break attack that will knock the enemy down. unless you hit the enemy while it’s down, it’ll get up and begin blocking again. there are never any weak-tiered enemies; current level enemies will always take a few knockdowns before being defeated. battles only occur in mobs and waves, with the exception of two enemy types and boss fights. one of those enemy types is a flyer that has a limited window of vulnerability, the other and bosses have constant super armor. so, they’re annoying in different ways.  spells and ranged attacks can’t be blocked. it goes without saying they’re the mainstay of your repertoire. arrows are boring, but cost no mana, cost nothing at all, so they are vastly more efficient. offensive spells come out instantly, with a few exceptions, but have bland particles and effects. there are utility and summon spells which I did not use myself, so I can’t fully comment on, but considering the games difficulty and how quickly enemies were dispatched, they’re probably more effort than they’re worth. it doesn’t matter how you fight, despite my criticisms. the only requirement to win is to have potions. they’re very cheap for being basically full heals. I don’t know what revival potions do, because I didn’t die, but I guess they revive you on the spot. my arsenal of 50 potions defeated the game.  easily the best part of fable is its level design. areas are distinct and there are no repetition. they are busy with detail, a careful labor. that being said, every single quest area in the game is a corridor. there are few change ups and they’re in the form of loops or alternate corridors, but the levels remain corridors. towns are, at least, more open affairs. they’re painstakingly detailed too, but there isn’t much to do in them. not a lot to shop for with only 4 tiers of weapons and armors. you can play games at the inn or attempt to bed faceless people and that’s the extent of things to do in town. models are soft and rounded, built to look like toys instead of things. the style is a touch of unique, able to convey realism and fantasy. every character model in the game is ugly despite this. there aren’t that many models either. the guys look like apes and the girls look like dolls. seeing the same ugly models everywhere starts to become distracting and annoying. even the main character is unattractive by default. fable’s scenario design is ok. the main quest is a everlong chain of meniality and fetching until the plot drops, the sidequests are only terrible things like defend quests, escort quests, and timed quests.  overall fable is of poor quality. featuring embarrassing writing and voice acting, limited and blindly executed combat, and uninspired scenario. it has fantastic music and environment design, maybe top tier in both respects, so it isn’t an absolute pain. it might as well be, though, as those aspects are passive quality. the irreverent simplicity of fable’s world did not impress. I want bite with my satire or development with my seriousness, not a work that stops short of either. what fable does have going for it is a combination of things that cannot be had or found in any other game. it’s partly to how npcs react to your character and definitely how it frames moral choices, but fable is an adventure all to itself. it being curious and an obvious work of passion is not enough to overcome its massive flaws. being interested in odd combinations, fable was enjoyable to a point, but I can’t call it any more than a dead average title.
